case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Cocanada Bank Ltd., Kakinada

facts.text: Appeals are Civil Appeals Nos. 55-157 of 1964 by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 8, 1961 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Case Referred No. 25 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos./55--157 1964. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 8, 1961 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Case Referred No. 25 of 1957.

facts.text: Cocanada Bank Ltd., Kakinada is a private limited company carrying on banking business with head office at Kakinada and a branch at Dayal Bagh.

anchor.surface_text: The, Cocanada Bank Ltd., Kakinada, hereinafter called the assessee, is a private limited companypany carrying on banking business with its head office at Kakinada and a branch at Dayal Bagh.

facts.text: Assessee's sources of income are banking business and interest from government securities.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees sources of income are banking business and interest from government securities.

facts.text: For assessment year 1949-50, assessee's income assessed as Interest on securities Rs. 84,880, Other banking activities Rs. 64,400 loss, Net loss Rs. 55,912.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 194950 its income was assessed as follows Interest on securities Rs. 84,880 Other banking activities Rs. 64,400  loss  ------------------ --- Net loss Rs. 55,912

facts.text: For business year 1950-51 (assessment year 1950-51), Interest on securities Rs. 5,191, income or loss Rs. 886, Total Rs. 6077 as decided by A.A.C.

anchor.surface_text: The following tabular form shows at a glance the factual position in regard to the income of the assessee under different heads during the said three years Business Year of assessment Interest on income or securities loss as finally Total decided by the A.A.C.

facts.text: For assessment year 1951-52, Interest on securities Rs. 2174, income or loss Rs. 1,177, Total Rs. 3351.
For assessment year 1952-53, Interest on securities Rs. 1885, income or loss Rs. 9,121, Total Rs. 11,006.

anchor.surface_text: 2. 1951-52 2174 1,177 3351 3. 1952-53 1885 9,121 11,006 For the three succeeding years the department showed the income under the said two separate heads

facts.text: Department allowed the loss to be set off against income under business head but disallowed against interest on securities for three succeeding years.

anchor.surface_text: For the three succeeding years the department showed the income under the said two separate heads but allowed the said loss to be set off against the income under the head business and disallowed it against the income under the head interest on securties.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer's view was confirmed on appeal by Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The view of the Income-tax Officer was companyfirmed, on appeal, by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and, on further appeal, by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer's view confirmed on further appeal by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The view of the Income-tax Officer was companyfirmed, on appeal, by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and, on further appeal, by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court: Whether assessee entitled to set off business loss of Rs. 55,912 from preceding year against entire income including interest on securities.

anchor.surface_text: The following question was referred by the Tribunal to the High Court for its opinion Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessee was entitled to set off the business loss of Rs. 55,912 brought forward from the preceding year against the entire income including interest on securities held by the assessee.

facts.text: High Court remitted case to Income-tax Tribunal citing United Commercial Bank Ltd. v. CIT decision.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, having regard to the decision of this Court in United Commercial Bank Ltd., Calcutta v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bangal 1  remitted the case to the Income- tax Tribunal, Hyderabad Bench,

facts.text: High Court remitted for fuller statement on whether securities formed part of trading assets in course of banking business and dealing with securities was part of business.

anchor.surface_text: for making a fuller statement of case on the question whether these securities in question formed part of the trading assets held by the assessee in the companyrse of its business as a banker and whether its dealing with the securities from which it received interest was as much the assessees business as receiving deposits from clients and withdrawals by them.

facts.text: Income-tax Tribunal held that receipt of interest from securities was as much the assessee's business as other banking activities like receiving deposits and withdrawals.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Tribunal, on a further hearing, held that the receipt of interest from securities was as much the assessees business as its other banking activities like receiving deposits from the clients and withdrawals by them.

facts.text: High Court answered the reference in favour of the assessee on receipt of supplementary statement from Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of the supplementary statement of case from the Tribunal the High Court answered the reference in favour of the assessee. Hence the present appeals.

facts.text: Revenue argued that income from business and securities fall under different heads s.10 and s.8, mutually exclusive, losses under business cannot be set off against securities income under s.24(2).

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the Revenue argued that the income from business and securities fell under different heads, namely, s. 10 and s. 8 of the Act respectively, that they were mutually exclusive and, therefore, the losses under the head business companyld number be carried forward from the preceding year to the succeeding year and set off under s. 22 4  of the Act against the income from securities held by the assessee.

facts.text: Assessee contended that securities were part of trading assets, income therefrom part of business income, so business losses can be set off against total business income including securities.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the assessee, on the other hand, companytended that though for the purpose of companyputation of income, the income from securities and the income from business were calculated separately, in a case where the securities were part of the trading assets of the business, the income therefrom was part of the income of the business and, therefore. the losses incurred under the head business companyld be set off during the succeeding years against the total income of the business, i.e., income from the business including the income from the securities.

facts.text: Tribunal and High Court found that securities were assessee's trading assets and income therefrom was income of the business.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal and the High Court found that they were the assessees trading assets and the income therefrom was, therefore, the income of the business.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that income from securities which are trading assets is income from business for set-off under s.24(2).

anchor.surface_text: If it was the income of the business, s. 24 2  of the Act was immediately attracted. If the income from the securities was the income from its business, the loss companyld, in terms of that section, be set off against that income.

facts.text: In Punjab Cooperative Bank case, Judicial Committee held securities of a bank are connected to its business of dealing with money and credit, keeping cash or realisable securities for depositors.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Committee in The Punjab Cooperative Bank Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab 1  has clearly brought out the business companynection between the securities of a bank and its business, thus In the ordinary case of a bank, the business companysists in its essence of dealing with money and credit. Numerous depositors place their money with the bank often receiv- ing a small rate of interest on it.

facts.text: Tribunal held on evidence that assessee invested in easily realisable securities, which were part of trading assets of banking business.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the Tribunal held, on the evidence, and that was accepted by the High Court, that the assessee was investing its amounts in easily realisable securities and, therefore, the said securities were part of the trading assets of the assessees banking business.

facts.text: V. Gupte, Solicitor-General, N. D. Karkhanis and R.N. Sachthey appeared for the appellant in all appeals.

anchor.surface_text: V. Gupte, Solicitor-General, N. D. Karkhanis and R.N. Sachthey, for the appellant  in all the appeals . S. Pathak, B. Datta and T. Satyanarayan, for the respondent  in all the appeals .

facts.text: S. Pathak, B. Datta and T. Satyanarayan appeared for the respondent in all appeals.

anchor.surface_text: S. Pathak, B. Datta and T. Satyanarayan, for the respondent  in all the appeals . The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Subba Rao, J.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Subba Rao, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Subba Rao, J. These appeals by special leave raise the question of companystruction of s. 24 2  of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922,
Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 8, 1961 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Case Referred No. 25 of 1957.
These appeals by special leave raise the question of construction of s. 24(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, hereinafter called the Act.
construction of s. 24 2  of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922, hereinafter called the Act. The material facts may briefly be stated. The, Cocanada Bank Ltd., Kakinada, hereinafter called the assessee,

The answer to this question depends upon the scope of s. 6 of the Act. Section 6 of the Act classified taxable income under the following several heads i salaries ii interest on securities iii income from property iv profits and gains of business, profession or vocation v income from other sources and capital gains.

concepts.interpretation: Classifies taxable income under different heads only for computation of net income; does not determine if income is part of business income, which is decided on commercial principles.

concepts.interpretation: Provides for intra-year set off between different heads; contrasted with sub-s.(2) which omits 'head' and focuses on same business.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessee was entitled to set off the business loss of Rs. 55,912 brought forward from the preceding year against the entire income including interest on securities held by the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The following question was referred by the Tribunal to the High Court for its opinion Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessee was entitled to set off the business loss of Rs. 55,912 brought forward from the preceding year against the entire income including interest on securities held by the assessee.

issues.text: whether these securities in question formed part of the trading assets held by the assessee in the course of its business as a banker and whether its dealing with the securities from which it received interest was as much the assessees business as receiving deposits from clients and withdrawals by them.

anchor.surface_text: remitted the case to the Income- tax Tribunal, Hyderabad Bench, for making a fuller statement of case on the question whether these securities in question formed part of the trading assets held by the assessee in the course of its business as a banker and whether its dealing with the securities from which it received interest was as much the assessees business as receiving deposits from clients and withdrawals by them.

issues.text: whether the securities formed part of the trading assets of the business and the income therefrom was income from the business.

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, is whether the securities formed part of the trading assets of the business and the income therefrom was income from the business. The answer to this question depends upon the scope of s. 6 of the Act.

issues.text: whether the income from business and securities fell under different heads, namely, s. 10 and s. 8 of the Act respectively, that they were mutually exclusive and, therefore, the losses under the head business could not be carried forward from the preceding year to the succeeding year and set off under s. 24(2) of the Act against the income from securities held by the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the Revenue argued that the income from business and securities fell under different heads, namely, s. 10 and s. 8 of the Act respectively, that they were mutually exclusive and, therefore, the losses under the head business could not be carried forward from the preceding year to the succeeding year and set off under s. 24(2) of the Act against the income from securities held by the assessee.

issues.text: Whether a particular income is part of the income from a business falls to be decided not on the basis of the provisions of s. 6 but on commercial principles.

anchor.surface_text: Whether a particular income is part of the income from a business falls to be decided not on the basis of the provisions of s. 6 but on commercial principles.

arguments.claim: Income from business under s.10 and from securities under s.8 fall under mutually exclusive heads, so business losses cannot be carried forward under s.24(2) and set off against securities income.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the Revenue argued that the income from business and securities fell under different heads, namely, s. 10 and s. 8 of the Act respectively, that they were mutually exclusive and, therefore, the losses under the head business could not be carried forward from the preceding year to the succeeding year and set off under s. 24 2  of the Act against the income from securities held by the assessee.

arguments.court_reasoning: Section 6 heads are only for computation of net income; does not determine if income is part of business income, which is decided on commercial principles.

arguments.claim: Where securities are part of trading assets of the business, income from securities is part of business income, so business losses can be set off against total business income including from securities.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the assessee, on the other hand, contended that though for the purpose of computation of income, the income from securities and the income from business were calculated separately, in a case where the securities were part of the trading assets of the business, the income therefrom was part of the income of the business and, therefore. the losses incurred under the head business could be set off during the succeeding years against the total income of the business, i.e., income from the business including the income from the securities.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ields the same result. While in sub-s. 1  the expression head is used in sub-s.  2  the said expression is companyspicuously omitted. This designed di

arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal and High Court found securities were trading assets; income therefrom is business income attracting s.24(2).

arguments.claim: Receipt of interest from securities is as much the assessee's business as other banking activities like receiving deposits and withdrawals.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Tribunal, on a further hearing, held that the receipt of interest from securities was as much the assessees business as its other banking activities like receiving deposits from the clients and withdrawals by them.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: erefrom had to be assessed under s. 8 of the Act. This decision does number say that the income from securities is number income from the business. No

arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal held on evidence, accepted by High Court and this Court.

arguments.claim: Section 6 classifies income under heads only for computation of net income; interest on securities does not cease to be business income if securities are trading assets.

anchor.surface_text: The answer to this question depends upon the scope of s. 6 of the Act. Section 6 of the Act classified taxable income under the following several heads i salaries ii interest on securities iii income from property iv profits and gains of business, profession or vocation v income from other sources and capital gains. The scheme of the Act is that income- tax is one tax. Section 6 only classifies the taxable income under different heads for the purpose of computation of the net income of the assessee.

arguments.claim: Whether particular income is part of business income decided on commercial principles, not s.6 provisions; securities form part of trading assets.

anchor.surface_text: Whether a particular income is part of the income from a business falls to be decided not on the basis of the provisions of s. 6 but on commercial principles. To put it in other words, did the securities in the present case which yielded the income form part of the trading assets of the assessee?

arguments.claim: Omission of 'head' in s.24(2) compared to s.24(1) is deliberate, allowing set off against same business profits regardless of heads under s.6.

anchor.surface_text: A comparative study of sub-ss. 1 and 2 of s. 24 yields the same result. While in sub-s. 1 the expression head is used in sub-s. 2 the said expression is conspicuously omitted. This designed distinction brings out the intention of the Legislature.

arguments.claim: Bank securities are connected to banking business of dealing with money and credit, kept as easily realisable for depositors.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Committee in The Punjab Cooperative Bank Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab 1 has clearly brought out the business connection between the securities of a bank and its business, thus In the ordinary case of a bank, the business consists in its essence of dealing with money and credit.

arguments.claim: United Commercial Bank held heads mutually exclusive for assessment under specific sections but does not say securities income is not business income.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of this Court in United Commercial Bank Ltd., Calcutta v. Commissioner of Income-tax, west Bengal 1 does not lay down any different proposition. It held... that even though the securities were part of the trading assets of the company doing business, the income therefrom had to be assessed under s. 8 of the Act. This decision does not say that the income from securities is not income from the business.

arguments.claim: East India Housing case held income from shops under s.9 but does not say it is not business income.

anchor.surface_text: Nor does the decision of this Court in East India Housing and Land Development. Trust Ltd., v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal 2 support the contention of the Revenue... This Court held that the said income fell under the specific head mentioned in s. 9 of the Act. This case also does not lay down that the income from the shops is not the income in the business.

arguments.claim: In Chugandas case, interest from securities formed part of business income for exemption under s.25(3); heads do not delimit sources of income.

anchor.surface_text: The limited scope of the earlier decision was explained by this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City Iv. Chugandas Co. 1 . Therein this Court held that interest from securities formed part of the assessees business income for the purpose of exemption under s. 25 3 . Shah, J., speaking for the Court, observed The heads described in s. 6... do not exhaustively delimit sources from which income arises.

holdings.text: Section 6 only classifies the taxable income under different heads for the purpose of computation of the net income of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 of the Act classified taxable income under the following several heads i salaries ii interest on securities iii income from property iv profits and gains of business, profession or vocation v income from other sources and capital gains. The scheme of the Act is that income- tax is one tax. Section 6 only classifies the taxable income under different heads for the purpose of computation of the net income of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of the Act treats income-tax as one tax; heads under s.6 are for computation only.

holdings.text: income by way of interest from securities does not cease to be part of the income from business if the securities are part of the trading assets.

anchor.surface_text: Though for the purpose of computation of the income, interest on securities is separately classified, income by way of interest from securities does not cease to be part of the income from business if the securities are part of the trading assets. Whether a particular income is part of the income from a business falls to be decided not on the basis of the provisions of s. 6 but on commercial principles.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Separate classification under s.6 does not override commercial characterization of income as business income.

holdings.text: Whether a particular income is part of the income from a business falls to be decided not on the basis of the provisions of s. 6 but on commercial principles.

anchor.surface_text: Whether a particular income is part of the income from a business falls to be decided not on the basis of the provisions of s. 6 but on commercial principles. To put it in other words, did the securities in the present case which yielded the income form part of the trading assets of the assessee?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Business income determination based on commercial principles independent of statutory heads.

holdings.text: The Tribunal and the High Court found that they were the assessees trading assets and the income therefrom was, therefore, the income of the business.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal and the High Court found that they were the assessees trading assets and the income therefrom was, therefore, the income of the business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts factual finding of lower courts that securities are trading assets.

holdings.text: If the income from the securities was the income from its business, the loss could, in terms of that section, be set off against that income.

anchor.surface_text: If it was the income of the business, s. 24 2  of the Act was immediately attracted. If the income from the securities was the income from its business, the loss could, in terms of that section, be set off against that income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.24(2) where securities income qualifies as business income.

holdings.text: While in sub-s. 1 the expression head is used in sub-s. 2 the said expression is conspicuously omitted. This designed distinction brings out the intention of the Legislature.

anchor.surface_text: A comparative study of sub-ss. 1 and 2 of s. 24 yields the same result. While in sub-s. 1 the expression head is used in sub-s. 2 the said expression is conspicuously omitted. This designed distinction brings out the intention of the Legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deliberate legislative omission in s.24(2) focuses on same business, not heads.

holdings.text: the assessee was investing its amounts in easily realisable securities and, therefore, the said securities were part of the trading assets of the assessees banking business.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the Tribunal held, on the evidence, and that was accepted by the High Court, that the assessee was investing its amounts in easily realisable securities and, therefore, the said securities were part of the trading assets of the assessees banking business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows securities held for liquidity in banking business, accepted from Tribunal.

holdings.text: This decision does not say that the income from securities is not income from the business.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of this Court in United Commercial Bank Ltd., Calcutta v. Commissioner of Income-tax, west Bengal 1 does not lay down any different proposition. ... This decision does not say that the income from securities is not income from the business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes United Commercial Bank: assessment under s.8 but still business income.

holdings.text: This case also does not lay down that the income from the shops is not the income in the business.

anchor.surface_text: Nor does the decision of this Court in East India Housing and Land Development. Trust Ltd., v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal 2 support the contention of the Revenue... This case also does not lay down that the income from the shops is not the income in the business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes East India Housing: specific head does not negate business character.

holdings.text: interest from securities formed part of the assessees business income for the purpose of exemption under s. 25(3).

anchor.surface_text: Therein this Court held that interest from securities formed part of the assessees business income for the purpose of exemption under s. 25 3 . Shah, J., speaking for the Court, observed The heads described in s. 6... do not exhaustively delimit sources from which income arises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Chugandas: heads do not delimit income sources; securities interest can be business income.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal and the High Court found that they were the assessees trading assets and the income therefrom was, therefore, the income of the business. If it was the income of the business, s. 24 2  of the Act was immediately attracted. If the income from the securities was the income from its business, the loss could, in terms of that section, be set off against that income.

outcome.relief_summary: Assessee entitled to carry forward business loss and set it off against profits from the same business including income from securities which are part of trading assets

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 of the Act classified taxable income under the following several heads i salaries ii interest on securities iii income from property iv profits and gains of business, profession or vocation v income from other sources and capital gains. The scheme of the Act is that income- tax is one tax. Section 6 only classifies the taxable income under different heads for the purpose of computation of the net income of the assessee.

The Tribunal and the High Court found that they were the assessees trading assets and the income therefrom was, therefore, the income of the business. If it was the income of the business, s. 24 2  of the Act was immediately attracted. If the income from the securities was the income from its business, the loss could, in terms of that section, be set off against that income.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the Tribunal held, on the evidence, and that was accepted by the High Court, that the assessee was investing its amounts in easily realisable securities and, therefore, the said securities were part of the trading assets of the assessees banking business.
